description: From Middle English hangen, hongen, from a fusion of Old English h≈çn (‚Äúto hang, be hanging‚Äù, intransitive verb) and hangian (‚Äúto hang, cause to hang‚Äù, transitive verb), from Proto-West Germanic *hƒÖÃÑhan and *hangƒìn; also probably influenced by Old Norse hengja (‚Äúto suspend‚Äù) and hanga (‚Äúto be suspended‚Äù); all from Proto-Germanic *hanhanƒÖ, *hangƒÅnƒÖ (compare Dutch hangen, Low German hangen and h√§ngen, German h√§ngen, Norwegian Bokm√•l henge, Norwegian Nynorsk henga), from Proto-Indo-European *·∏±enk- (‚Äúto waver, be in suspense‚Äù) (compare Gothic êå∑êå∞êå∑êå∞êåΩ (hƒÅhan), Hittite íÇµíÄÄíÄ≠íÇµ (/kƒÅnk-/, ‚Äúto hang‚Äù), Sanskrit ‡§∂‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡§§‡•á (≈õ√°·πÖkate, ‚Äúis in doubt, hesitates‚Äù), Latin c≈´nctƒÅrƒ´ (‚Äúto delay‚Äù)).

entries.meaning: The way in which something hangs.
examples: This skirt has a nice hang.

entries.meaning: A mass of hanging material.
A slackening of motion.
A sharp or steep declivity or slope.
(computing) An instance of ceasing to respond to input.
examples: We sometimes get system hangs.

entries.meaning: (informal, figuratively) A grip, understanding.
The smallest amount of concern or consideration; a damn.
examples: I don't give a hang.
They don't seem to care a hang about the consequences.

entries.meaning: A hangout.
A person that someone hangs out with.

verbs.description: hang (third-person singular simple present hangs, present participle hanging, simple past and past participle hung or (legal) hanged)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To be or remain suspended.
examples: The lights hung from the ceiling.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To float, as if suspended.
examples: The smoke hung in the room.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To veer in one direction.
examples: The jockey claimed that the horse hung towards the outside

entries.meaning: (intransitive, of a ball in cricket, tennis, etc.) To rebound unexpectedly or unusually slowly, due to backward spin on the ball or imperfections of the ground.
(transitive) To hold or bear in a suspended or inclined manner or position instead of erect.
examples: He hung his head in shame.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To cause (something) to be suspended, as from a hook, hanger, hinges, or the like.
examples: Hang those lights from the ceiling.
to hang a door

entries.meaning: (transitive, law) To kill (someone) by suspension from the neck, usually as a form of execution or suicide.
examples: The culprits were hanged from the nearest tree.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, law) To be executed by suspension by one's neck from a gallows, a tree, or other raised bar, attached by a rope tied into a noose.
examples: You will hang for this, my friend.

entries.meaning: (transitive, informal) (used in maledictions) To damn.
(intransitive, informal) To loiter; to hang around; to spend time idly.
examples: Synonym: hang out
I didn't see anything, officer. I was just hanging.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To exhibit (an object) by hanging.
(transitive) To apply (wallpaper or drywall to a wall).
examples: Let's hang this cute animal design in the nursery.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To decorate (something) with hanging objects.
examples: Let's hang the nursery with some new wallpaper.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, figuratively) To remain persistently in one's thoughts.
(transitive) To prevent from reaching a decision, especially by refusing to join in a verdict that must be unanimous.
examples: One obstinate juror can hang a jury.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, computing) To stop responding to manual input devices such as the keyboard and mouse.
examples: The computer has hung again. Not even pressing <Ctrl>+<Alt>+<Del> works.
When I push this button the program hangs.

entries.meaning: (transitive, computing) To cause (a program or computer) to stop responding.
examples: The program has a bug that can hang the system.

entries.meaning: (transitive, chess) To cause (a piece) to become vulnerable to capture.
examples: If you move there, you'll hang your rook.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, chess) To be vulnerable to capture.
examples: In this standard opening position White has to be careful because the pawn on e4 hangs.

entries.meaning: (transitive, baseball, slang, of a pitcher) To throw a hittable off-speed pitch.
(transitive, figurative) To attach or cause to stick (a charge or accusation, etc.).
examples: There were no whisperings, even from his opponents, that he was no better than he ought to be. Because, there was nothing wrong on which to hang a charge. As an eloquent orator, he carried with him the firm support of a good name.

description: From hang sangwich, Irish colloquial pronunciation of ham sandwich.

entries.meaning: (Ireland, informal, derogatory) Cheap processed ham (cured pork), often made specially for sandwiches.
Alternative spelling of Hang (‚Äúmusical instrument‚Äù)
